newsitem.title: USA: Wall Street stocks seen opening mixed to lower.
newsitem.headline: Wall Street stocks seen opening mixed to lower.

text.p: Wall Street stocks are expected to open mixed to slightly lower Monday, based on lower futures numbers and a lack of major news from over the weekend, analysts said.

"My guess is we are going to get a down opening. The futures prices would suggest it and there was no news over the weekend to move it higher or lower," said Thom Brown managing director of Rutherford Brown and Catherwood.
The Standard & Poor's 500 futures were off 1.20 at 861.30. The 30-year bond was down 5/32 at a 6.79 percent yield.
Analysts said they expected to see some profit taking after Friday's rise to a new record high. The Dow industrials rallied 130 points Friday, breaking through to 7436.
"You might see some profit taking after Friday's moon shot, but after that it is anyone's guess," said Larry Wachtel, an analyst at Prudential Securities.
Peter Cardillo, director of research at Westfalia Investments, said he expected the early profit taking to yield to even more record highs.
"My guess is the psychological barrier of 7500 is going to be tested today," he said. "I think the green light is on for a short-term pop up."
Analysts added that Microsoft Corp's announcement that it would invest about $1 billion in cable television operator Comcast Corp may boost cable stocks.

Japan's Nikkei-225 index finished off 2.40 points, or 0.01 percent, lower at 20,485.75. In London, the FTSE 100 was up 13.9 points at 4658.9. U.S. stocks were firm there as a weaker U.S. dollar attracted European investors.
The dollar was battered against the yen due to concerns about Japan's trade surplus, trading at 112.33/38 yen. In Europe, it was at 1.7112/22 marks.

The Wall Street Journal said in its Heard on the Street column that leveraged-buyout funds have hit some snags recently in the competitive LBO market. With about $35 billion estimated for LBO funds this year, the players are facing high multiples and are saddled with some difficult companies.

The New York Times said in its Market Place column that mutual fund investors are less enthusiastic about technology stocks. For the week ended last Wednesday, investors took $62.5 million out of technology funds, making it the worst week since October, the paper said.
